text: The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs has been a junior position in the British government since 1782, subordinate to both the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs and since 1945 also to the Minister of State for Foreign Affairs. The post has been based at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, which was created in 1968, by the merger of the Foreign Office, where the position was initially based, and the Commonwealth Office. Notable holders of the office include Granville Leveson-Gower, 2nd Earl Granville, John Wodehouse, 1st Earl of Kimberley, Edward Grey, 1st Viscount Grey of Fallodon, George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston, and Anthony Eden. ==Parliamentary Under-Secretaries of State for Foreign Affairs, 1782–1968== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- ! colspan="2" |Name !Portrait!! colspan="2" | Term of office !Political party ! colspan="2" |P.M. !F.Sec. |- | |William Fraser |60px |1782 |1789 | | | | |- ! style="background-color: " | |Richard Brinsley Sheridan |60px |1782 |1782 | rowspan="3" |Whig |! style="background-color: " | |The Marquess of Rockingham |Fox |- ! rowspan="2" style="background-color: " | | rowspan="2" |George Maddison | rowspan="2" |60px | rowspan="2" |1782 | rowspan="2" |1783 |! style="background-color: " | |The Earl of Shelburne |The Lord Grantham |- |! style="background-color: " | |The Duke of Portland |Fox |- | rowspan="2" | | rowspan="2" |St Andrew St John | rowspan="2" |60px | rowspan="2" |1783 | rowspan="2" |1789 | rowspan="2" | | rowspan="8" style="background-color: " ! | | rowspan="8" |Pitt the Younger |The Earl Temple |- | rowspan="3" |The Duke of Leeds |- ! style="background-color: " | |Hon.
